contentrichtext.text: {{for|the Nissan automobile|Nissan Pixo}} {{Infobox company | name = Pixo | logo = | caption = | type = | genre = | fate = Acquired | predecessor = | successor = [[Sun Microsystems]] | foundation = {{Start date|1994}} | founder = Paul Mercer | defunct = {{End date|2003}} | location_city = | location_country = | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = [[Mobile software]] | products = Pixo OS | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Pixo''' was a company that developed infrastructure for hand-held devices. It was founded in 1994 when Paul Mercer, a software developer at [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], left to form his own company.<ref name="nyt">{{Citation | last = Markoff | first = John | title = He Helped Build the iPod; Now He Has Built a Rival | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/27/technology/27mercer.html?ei=5088&en=7ca4508916893a7f&ex=1298696400&pagewanted=all | accessdate = 4 January 2011 | date=27 February 2006}}</ref> The company developed a system software toolkit in [[C++]]<ref>{{Citation | last = Stroustrup | first = Bjarne | author-link = Bjarne Stroustrup | title = C++ Applications | url = http://www.stroustrup.com/applications.html | accessdate = 26 August 2012 }}</ref> for use on cell phones and other hand-held devices. They were acquired by [[Sun Microsystems]] in 2003.<ref name="nyt"/> ==Pixo OS and use in Apple's iPod== In 2001, Pixo was hired by Apple to adapt their system software for use in the [[iPod]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Yi | first = Matthew | title = Little-known startup was behind iPod's easy-to-use interface | newspaper = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] | url = http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/Little-known-startup-was-behind-iPod-s-2733248.php | accessdate = 2012 November 10}}</ref> The use of the Pixo OS in the iPod was never formally announced, although the first-generation iPod's "About iPod" display includes a mention of Pixo, and a [[Connectix]] biography of their VP of engineering [[Mike Neil]] mentions his role as "lead architect on the Pixo OS that is used in ... the Apple iPod".<ref>{{Wayback|url=http://www.connectix.com/about/bios.html|title=About Connectix|date=20030806065941}}</ref> Apple acquired the Pixo OS shortly after shipping the iPod{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} and removed mention of Pixo from the "About iPod" display with a firmware update to the first-generation iPod. On April 9, 2007, Apple [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Steve Jobs]] announced the shipment of its 100 millionth iPod,<ref> {{Citation | title = 100 Million iPods Sold | url = http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2007/04/09ipod.html | accessdate = 4 January 2011 }}</ref> making the Pixo OS one of the most widely used [[embedded operating system]]s. As of 2011, Pixo OS continued to be used on the [[iPod Classic]] and [[iPod Nano]], which do not run [[iOS]].<ref> {{cite web |publisher= Ars Technica |url= http://arstechnica.com/apple/2011/01/6g-ipod-nano-hack-just-beginning-of-long-road-to-nano-apps/ |title= 6G iPod nano hack just beginning of long road to nano apps |date= 3 January 2011 |accessdate= 2012-09-13 }} </ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Wayback|url=http://www.pixo.com|title=Pixo.com website}} *{{Wayback|url=http://pixo.com/products/products001.htm|date=20010815050140|title=Capabilities and features of the Pixo OS Platform 2.1}} *{{Wayback|url=http://www.sun.com/smi/Press/sunflash/2003-07/sunflash.20030717.1.xml|title=Sun Press Release announcing completion of acquisition|date=20070117072326}} *[http://www.designinginteractions.com/interviews/PaulMercer Bill Mogridge video interview of Paul Mercers involvement in the design of the iPod] [[Category:Companies established in 1996]] [[Category:IPod software]] [[Category:Sun Microsystems acquisitions]] [[Category:Companies disestablished in 2003]]
